theText: I suppose that to sayWednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1313 Wednesday, 21 September 1994 (No.2) 1994 Cognate bills: WINE GRAPES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1994 Consideration resumed from 28 June. Second Reading That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) is to introduce amendments to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980, Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993, Farm Household Support Act 1992, Fisheries Administration Act 1991, Fisheries Management Act 1991, National Residue Survey Administration Act 1992, Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, Wheat Marketing Act 1989, Wool Legislation (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Act 1993, Wool Tax Act (No.3) 1964 and the Sugar Cane Levy Act 1987. In addition, there are several acts that require a minor amendment relating to the change of name of the 'Australian Agricultural Council' to the 'Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand'. The amendments to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 concern levy payers to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. Small winemakers often forward grapes to another, usually larger, winemaker who converts the material into wine under instructions for a fee. This is called toll processing. The wine is then returned to the smaller winemaker for him or her to market. The smaller winemaker owns the wine throughout the process. Under the current legislation, the larger winemaker is the producer and is liable for levy on the wine. This cost is usually added to the fee charged to the smaller winemaker. The smaller winemaker is therefore the effective, but not the official, levy payer and accordingly is not entitled to attend, debate or vote in the industry annual general meeting of the corporation. The amendments proposed will permit small winemakers who toll process to pay levy directly and to accept the rights and obligations of levy payers. By redefining the term 'producer' for the purpose of the wine grapes levy under the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 and replacing the term 'winemaker' with 'producer' in part IVB of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980, which relates to annual general

theText: Minister for Resources) (10.01 a.m.)-I move:1314 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 September 1994 meetings of the industry, small winemakers will become the official levy payers in their own right and will be able to represent their own interests to the corporation. The amendments to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993 are for two main purposes. Firstly, they wiII ensure that ecologically sustainable development principles are written into the charter of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation and that the membership of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation board will include, in future, expertise in environmental and ecological matters. The Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation will therefore need to take ecologically sustainable development principles into account in its corporate planning and annual reporting and in determining priorities for allocation of research and development funds. This provision is now a feature of all research and development statutory authorities in my portfolio and is in accordance with government policy on ecologically sustainable development. Secondly, the amendments will provide for the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation to allocate funds received from patents or trademarks associated with non-research and development activities to activities other than research and development. The most significant of these non-research and development activities will be the revenue from the commercialisation of the wool mark. The amendments to the Farm Household Support Act 1992 implement a range of measures to improve the delivery of farm household support to farmers experiencing financial difficulties and to improve the administration of farm household support. Farmers applying for farm household support will have a longer period to provide proof that they are unable to access further commercial finance. If farm household support recipients are dissatisfied with a decision in relation to the extension of their grant periods, they will have improved mechanisms to seek a review of such decisions. This will complement the current mechanism of an appeal direct to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. These amendments also allow for improved administration of farm household support by providing a power for the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to delegate his or her powers under the act. To assist with management of the loan portfolio, and to ensure that all eligible recipients receive the benefit of the conversion of nine months of their farm household support payments to a grant, all farm household support recipients will be required to notify the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy of certain changes in their circumstances. There is currently no provision in the Farm Household Support Act 1992 to prevent a person who has received a lump sum farm household support payment upon the sale of their farm from receiving farm household support at a later stage and again selling a farm and receiving another such payment. These amendments ensure that a person may receive only one such payment. This will ensure that the funds available for this purpose are directed equitably to those who are committed to re-establishing their families outside the farm sector. The report on the adequacy of fisheries legislation, presented by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in December 1993, recommended a number of amendments to fisheries legislation. A majority of the recommended changes will improve the operation of the legislation and it is opportune to include the technical amendments in this bill. During the inquiry, the Australian Fisheries Wednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1315 Management Authority identified some further technical amendments to improve the effectiveness of the legislation. These have also been included in this bill. Technical amendments are proposed to the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 to clarify the sources of funds available to the Australian Fisheries Management Authority. Another amendment recognises the amalgamation of the ministerial councils responsible for fisheries and forestry. The amalgamation results from the decision of the Council of Australian Governments to reduce the number of ministerial councils. The amendments that are proposed to the Fisheries Management Act 1991 will allow fishing permit holders greater nexibility in nominating the boat to be used with their permit. In addition, this bill clarifies the emergency powers available to the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to manage fisheries and some powers and obligations of fisheries officers. The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 is amended to eliminate an anomaly in funding arrangements for the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation. The amended provision will ensure that research contributions from state licensed fishermen that are paid directly to the corporation or to consolidated revenue can be matched by the Commonwealth as originally intended. The amendments to the National Residue Survey Administration Act 1992, which were at the request of the cattle industry, will broaden the scope of the survey to encompass animal feeds and fibre products. This will enable industries to have a wider picture of likely contaminants in the food chain and lead to earlier intervention if contaminants are detected. This will be supplemented by the national residue survey having the facilities, at industry's instigation, to fund educational and extension programs from the national residue survey's account. This will lead to a more efficient survey and give industry a stronger role in ensuring that its commodity is, indeed, clean and green, and far more competitive on domestic and international markets. The main amendment to the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 extends the definition of 'grain'. The amendment is necessary following the transfer to the Australian Wheat Board of the seed testing facilities of the Victorian Department of Agriculture. The transfer is beneficial to, and is supported by, the grains and seeds industries. The new definition of 'grain' extends the coverage from the common cereal grains to horticultural, pasture and tree seeds, but only for the purposes of seed testing and seed certification. The Australian Wheat Board will not be able to use its marketing and trading powers for horticultural, pasture and tree seeds as it does not wish to undertake such activities. The Wheat Marketing Act 1989 is also being amended to allow for regulations to be made which will make it mandatory, rather than voluntary as at present, for wheat levy payers and collectors to provide certain information conceming the levy payment. The information is used for the management of the wheat industry fund and the allocation to individual levy payers of equity in the fund. An administrative amendment to the act will remove the 65-year age limit restriction on persons appointed to the board of the Australian Wheat Board. The following amendments included in this bill are of a procedural nature directed to improving the administration of the issues dealt with in those acts. The amendment to the Wool Legislation (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Act 1993 corrects an error in a date. 1316 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 September 1994 The amendments to the Wool Tax Act (No.3) 1964 are of a procedural nature and remove all references to 'registered' from the title of wool dealers because such a reference is now obsolete. The amendment to the definition of sugar industry organisations contained in the Sugar Cane Levy Act 1987 is necessary following the consolidation of the sugar industry organisations currently listed within the act. The amendments to the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council Act 1984, Biological Control Act 1984, Rural Industries Research (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1985, Rural Industries Research Act 1985, Pig Industry Act 1986, Horticultural Policy Council Act 1987, Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989 and the Primary Industries Council Act 1991 result from the amalgamation of the former ministerial councils that dealt with agriculture, water resources, soil conservation and rural adjustment issues into the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand. Of these pre-existing ministerial councils, the Australian Agriculture Council was referred to in these acts. It is necessary, therefore, that these acts be amended. I commend the bill to honourable members. WINE GRAPES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1994 The purpose of the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill is to revise the arrangements for levies paid under the Wine Grapes Levy Act 1979 as amended, 'the act'. The government is making these changes at the request of the winemaking industry. The act imposes a levy on winemakers. The 'marketing component' of the levy funds the operations of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The corporation's statutory responsibilities include wine promotion, wine export control, the wine label integrity program, and determining Australia's geographical indications for use in describing and presenting wine. The 'research component' of the levy supports the operations of the Grape and Wine Research and Development Corporation. This corporation has the statutory responsibility to coordinate and fund research and development undertaken on behalf of the grape and wine industry. The government provides matching funding for research and development expenditure on a dollar for dollar basis. It is worthwhile noting that to date levy rates have been set and altered at the request of industry. I do not anticipate that this will change. At present, the legislation specifies a complex range of levy rates for the marketing component. This makes for an unwieldy process when changing the levy rates for the marketing component. The bill instead provides that the levy rates will be set out in regulations, as is the usual case for horticultural levies. This will facilitate execution of industry requests to change the levy and bring it into line with normal practice. At the same time a maximum amount-0.5 per cent of the gross value of production-is set for the marketing component. The act already provides that the levy rates for the research component be specified by regulation. The research levy rate is at present $1.90 per tonne and the legislation sets a limit of $2 per tonne for this levy. The maximum was set in the original act of 1979 and needs to be raised to $3 per tonne to enable the industry to increase its funding of industry research and development, if it so desires. The bill also ends the exemption that smaller winemakers, those processing less than 10 tonnes of product, had from paying levy. As non-payers, those winemakers have no representation in the decisions and operations of the corporation and its regulatory functions. Wednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1317 It is intended that these winemakers will pay the small annual fee that constitutes the minimum levy rate, in return for which they will have the right to represent their interests at annual general meetings of the corporation and to receive the services and information that the corporation provides to its levy payers. Honourable members will be aware that the corporation's role is of considerable importance in the Australian wine industry'S drive to reach an annual export level of $1 billion by the year 2000. Many small producers will not be exporters, but the changes in the domestic market directly affect them. Such changes include the effects of expanded trade on grape supplies and Australia's commitment to end the use of European geographical indications in labelling our wine. It is important that the small winemakers not be left out of consideration in the strategic development of the Australian wine industry. It is important that their voice be heard. Their present ineligibility to be members of the AWBC prevents them from having the opportunity. The bill is intended to redress this situation. I commend this bill to honourable members. The purpose of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill is to amend the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991, the 'collection act', to allow small wine producers to pay levy in their own right and represent themselves at annual general meetings of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. Small winemakers often forward grapes to another, usually larger, winemaker who converts the material into wine under instructions for a fee, known as 'toll processing'. The wine is then returned to the smaller winemaker for him or her to market. The smaller winemaker owns the wine throughout the process. Under the current legislation, the larger winemaker is the 'producer' and is liable for levy on the wine. This cost is usually added to the fee charged to the smaller winemaker. The smaller winemaker is therefore the effective, but not the official, levy payer and accordingly is not entitled to attend, debate or vote in the industry annual general meeting of the corporation. The amendments proposed will permit small winemakers who toll process to pay levy directly and to accept the rights and obligations of levy payers. Although the legislation will allow small winemakers who have their wines toll processed to be recognised as the official levy payers, the government has put forward the related Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994 to ensure that product from small winemakers is leviable product. By redefining 'producer' for the purposes of the wine grapes levy under the collection act, small winemakers will become the official levy payers in their own right and will be able to represent their own interests to the corporation. I commend the bill to honourable members. The National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill provides for an increase in the maximum rate of levy under the national residue survey for meat chick1318 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 September 1994 ens. The increase has been requested by the peak industry body, the Australian Chicken Meat Federation, in order to maintain flexibility for changes to,the survey programs required for the chicken meat industry in the coming years. I commend the bill to honourable members. deals with cognate debate. This morning the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer ( Mr Elliott) sought leave for certain bills to be declared cognate. That has been done: there are now four bills that are being considered in cognate debate. The standing order states: ... the Minister, in moving that the first of the bills be read a second time, and Members in speaking in the subsequent debate, may refer to the subject matter of all the bills. So whilst there is only one motion before us, that the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) be read a second time, all four bills can be referred to in debate. Subsequently, when we have dispensed with the motion for the second reading of the primary industries bill, we wiII then move formally the motions for the second readings of the other bi\ls. Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1994 is being debated here today in cognate. The other three bills are the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment BiII 1994, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment BiII1994. The four pieces of legislation cover an amazing array of primary industries. It is perhaps a timely reminder to us all that primary industry in Australia covers a most diverse and dynamic spectrum of products, people and markets. It is most heartening to observe a common theme running through these four bills. It is the strong desire within those who work in and for our primary industries to help themselves. The coalition will be moving an amendment to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment BiII (No.2), and I will deal with it at the conclusion of my contribution to this debate. The National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill 1994 provides for the maximum rate of the national residue survey levy to increase from 0.02 per cent per head to 0.06 per cent per head. Almost all primary industries in Australia contribute to a national residue survey in order to ensure the food they produce is free of harmful residues. The survey for each particular industry is now fully funded by the industry itself. It is an industry helping itself by ensuring it contributes to, in this case, the national residue survey. In this case, the Chicken Meat Federation sought the increase in order to incorporate greater flexibility into the industry'S long-term planning. The coalition supports this legislation. It is perhaps timely to consider the value of the chicken meat industry. So often we consider the primary industries legislation and the impact that it has on Australia very much in the context of the big ticket items such as wheat, wool, beef and other agricultural products; often we do not give the due importance that we should to the chicken meat industry because it is a very large and expanding industry. As I said, as an industry it receives little publicity but it has quietly transformed itself from its backyard status-most recently as late as the 196Os-to a modem, dynamic industry which places second only to beef in the meat production stakes. speaker: Mr Bruce Scott (Maranoa) (10.19 A.m.)
theText: The Primary Industries and EnergyWednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1319 consumed about three miIlion birds annually, or less than half a kilogram of chicken meat each over the course of a year. The situation is -ow radically different. In 1993-94, we collectively munched our way through 325 million birds. That is a surprising figure: 325 million chickens includes 650 million drumsticks which equates to a consumption level of 27.4 kilograms of chicken meat per capita. It is quite easy from those figures to see how our diet in Australia is changing. Of course, because of the product and because of the value of chicken meat, the chicken meat industry is certainly taking a very large chunk out of the traditional meat industry'S per capita consumption. They are certainly surprising figures. To put that in perspective, each Austmlian consumed the equivalent of two Kentucky Fried Chicken snack packs or three McChickens or perhaps 13 bowls of chicken noodle soup each week for a whole year. Suffice to say, we Australians like our chicken. Not only do we enjoy the taste and health benefits of chicken meat; we gain substantially from the economic benefits of the industry. The chicken meat industry directly employs about 16,000 people and about 45,000 people are indirectly involved. The current value of sales at a retail level is approaching $1.7 billion. I think it is timely to point out that because this is an intensive animal feeding industry it is going to be affected by the drought. The cost of grain in Australia has been brought about and may be a direct result of the raging drought that we have seen across the eastern states of Australia over the last four years. Grain prices for the chicken meat industry are going to rise and they have already risen. That is going to place an increasing burden on the viability of the chicken meat industry. In tum, those costs have either got to be absorbed by the industry or passed on to the consumer. If they pass directly on to the consumer, we are going to see an inflationary impact on the Australian nation. This drought has wider ramifications than the plight of those who are directly involved who we see on a day-to-day basis in the rural electorates of Australia. It will impact on the national economy; it will impact on the CPI-the consumer price index, the cost of living in Australia. That is a direct result of the drought. That is why we do need to see from the government today a national response to this great tragedy that is out there in rural Australia. It does deserve, albeit too late for many, a national response. That national response must cover the impact that this drought is having on communities, families and industries because it is a national disaster. There is enormous potential for export development but the industry in Australia remains hamstrung by the high cost of capital, the high cost of labour and other inputs, and the subsidies provided to the chicken meat industry in competing countries. The United States and the European Union are particularly aggressive protectors of their domestic chicken meat industries. Thailand has rapidly assumed a prominent position amongst the world's chicken meat exporters by relying on tax incentives to lure foreign investment, and cheap labour, to build a most efficient industry in that country. The possible relaxation of Australian quarantine regulations relating to imported chicken meat is of great concern to the domestic industry. This concern is twofold. Naturally, there is concern for the impact on local producers, but just as important is the concern for the possible introduction of the world's most feared disease in the poultry industry, the Newcastle virus. I applaud the chicken meat industry for the high standards it supports and upholds-in particular, with regard to its approach to hygiene, disease eradication and quality control. I sincerely hope that the industry'S commitment to development and innovation is matched by 1320 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 September 1994 a similar level of commitment from the federal government to eliminate factors which impede the industry's growth, whilst maintaining secure quarantine restrictions. We all benefit from agricultural products in Australia which are clean and green and are the envy of many other countries in the world. The Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill 1994 end the current levy exemption for wine producers producing less than 10 tonnes of fresh grapes, place a maximum limit on the amount of levy that is used to support marketing, and increase the limit on the research and development component. A proportion of the money raised through the wine grapes levy finances the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. This body is responsible for wine promotion, administration of the wine label integrity program, export control and determining Australia's geographical indications for use in describing and presenting wine. The remainder funds the Grape and Wine Research and Development Corporation. Funding spent on research is matched by the government on a dollar for dollar basis. I understand that both the Australian Wine Makers Forum and the Independent Winemakers, both of which represent small winemakers, support the alteration proposed by this legislation. The coalition will be supporting the legislation. The Australian wine industry continues to be a primary industry of great success. As the reputation of our wine spreads throughout the world, our export trade continues to strengthen. In 1994-95, it is estimated we will export 162 million litres of wine. This amounts to an increase of almost 400 per cent since 1989-90. In value terms, the exports are expected to come close to $500 million. One of the most exciting developments in the wine industry is the agreement reached between Australia and the European Community, which was negotiated late in 1992 and signed in January this year. This agreement will result in the improved access of Australian wine to European markets and eliminate technical trade barriers, in return for the phasing out of the use of European geographical names as names for Australian wine. The search for new names to replace beaujolais, hock, madeira, chianti and, eventually, champagne, chablis, moselle and many others will be a challenge for Australian winemakers. It does, however, provide an enormous opportunity for Australian wines to further establish their particular market niche with distinctive and unique names. It will be a formidable task to educate the wine drinkers of the world to accept the new names. I do not underestimate that task, because people have for so long associated the variety of a wine with a region, and it is going to be extremely difficult and a great challenge, obviously, to the wine industry to develop new names which will be identifiable the world over. However, for an industry which has displayed enormous marketing and product development prowess, I feel that it is a challenge to which the wine industry is certainly capable of rising. I recently noticed an Australian wine selling under the name of 'Antarctic White'. That seemed to me to be an excellent example of a name which provides a clear impression of the wine's style whilst also establishing the wine's geographic origin. example of the wine industry's foresight and vision. I have no doubt that the industry will achieve its $1 billion annual exports target set for the year 2000. It is a wonderful example to us all to see that an industry out there has a target which it wants to achieve; it has a plan.

speaker: Mr Bruce Scott
theText: I am getting to my electorate very shortly. This agreement is a greatWednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITIEE 1321 We can only wish the wine industry well, and let us hope that it does reach that target before the year 2000. It is very important that we consider the impact the drought is having on our Australian wine industry. In my electorate, in the granite belt, we have got an emerging wine industry. It has been there for a long time, but it is expanding. One of the limiting factors to the expansion of that wine industry is water. It is time that this nation looked more seriously at a national water strategy. We so often find that our agricultural potential is limited by the impact of drought. Whilst we look at the social issues, I do not think we have looked fully at trying to drought proof Australia through the implementation of a national water strategy. That is a debate that deserves the attention of all Australians. I will now address the final piece of legislation which we are considering in this cognate debate. The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1994 covers a range of small changes to various primary industry acts. I wiII confine my comments this morning to the amendments proposed to the Farm Household Support Act 1992. This act governs the operation of the farm household support scheme, designed to provide assistance to farmers who are unable to meet day-to-day living expenses and who cannot access commercial finance. The scheme also provides a financial incentive for farmers wishing to leave the industry. To qualify for farm household support, the applicant must be an Australian farmer between 16 years of age and the pension age, with a certificate of inability to obtain finance. The assistance is provided for a period of nine months. If during that time the farmer leaves the farm, the assistance becomes a grant. If the farmer remains in the industry, the assistance must be repaid at commercial interest rates. Those who leave the industry within the nine-month period will receive the balance payable for the period as a lump sum, in addition to their re-establishment grant of $45,000. This bill makes a small but important change to the administrative arrangements for farm household support. It extends, from 14 to 30 days, the time allowed for farm household support applicants to obtain a certificate of inability to access finance. A great number of farmers have experienced difficulty in obtaining a certificate within 14 days, owing largely to the obvious problems they face in physically accessing financial institutions. I am pleased that the government has acknowledged this difficulty and acted in the manner that it has in this bill. Although the farm household support scheme is, in theory, a useful mode of assistance to farmers who face insurmountable financial difficulties, its practical application has proved to be thwarted by inconsistencies and anomalies. For example, the re-establishment payments are limited to one per farm, regardless of the number of people or families who work on that farm. In the event of two families running one farm in cooperation, only one can receive the re-establishment grant. One wonders what happens to the other family. It also strikes me as particularly counterproductive for farm household support to be converted to a loan for those who do not \eave farming. The assistance is provided, after alI, for those who cannot obtain commercial finance. It seems perfectly obvious that the last thing these people need is another loan. It is also important to remember that leaving farming is not such an easy task at the moment. Many producers right through the drought areas of Australia who make a decision to leave find it impossible to sell and liquidate their farm in order to move off that land within nine 1322 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 September 1994 months. They have assets which may have a paper value but have no resale value in the current circumstances. So the legislation is quite ludicrous in its application. Some drought-ravaged farmers literally cannot give their farms away. So despite their best efforts farmers will still find themselves unable to access further commercial finance and incurring another debt because they go over the nine-month limit for moving off their land. Their inability to access further finance is the reason they went onto farm household support in the first place but once they access farm household support they have their feet on the sticky paper and cannot get them off. Unable to access finance, they are caught in a trap, all of which demonstrates the government's insensitive treatment of farmers around Australia, particularly in these drought ravaged times. It is not surprising then that only 392 farmers are currently accessing farm household support. The government itself estimated that at least 1,200 would access this support. Government members were congratulating themselves because they were going to be giving household support to farmers in these very difficult times, but the farmers know that once they access that farm household support it is a one-way ticket off the farm and that if they do not go they have incurred another loan, which will incur commercial rates of interest after nine months. It is the policy of the coalition to allow farm household support to be provided as a grant for 12 months, irrespective of whether the farmer chooses to leave the industry. This clearly recognises the need to provide assistance to meet day-to-day needs without creating additional debts. I will be moving an amendment on behalf of the coalition which encourages the government to adopt our strategy for administering farm household support. I would hope that the government will accept our amendment. Any of those government members who have been out to the drought areas and have been in touch with the farmers, the farm industry leaders and church organisations such as Lifeline and the Salvation Army will know that farm household support as it applies under government legislation is failing. It is all very well to decide at a round table conference to give $25 million to ANL and to offer the people of Sydney $150 million overnight to remove the Cahill Expressway, but it is not good enough to support farm households with income support for 12 months without strings attached. This callous approach of the government must be changed. I hope the opposition's amendment will be accepted. The amendment also calls on the government to modify the assets test applied to other forms of assistance. There is no doubt that the assets tests applied to benefits such as jobsearch, family payment and Austudy are denying farmers access to assistance to which they and their families are clearly entitled. I sincerely hope that the government addresses this problem in the course of its cabinet deliberations today. The true tragedy is that whatever rabbit the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) are able to pull from the hat today, it will simply be too late for many farmers. It will certainly be too late for many students who have already been forced to interrupt their study program because their parents can no longer continue to keep them living away from home whilst they gain access to tertiary studies. It will be too late for those skilled and experienced farmers who have already left the industry. It will also be too late for the marriages and relationships which have endured unbearable Wednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1323 strain over the past two, three and four years. The government must bear the fun brunt of the blame for these consequences, most of which are due entirely to its inaction. The Prime Minister made a statement that drought in this country is a normal occurrence and a part of rural life. I hope that, when he went to Central Queensland and the Darling Downs, what he saw there was not a normal part of rural life. The government's silence on this issue still indicates to the opposition that it does not understand the plight of those in rural Australia. We are not only talking about those on the land. We are also talking about the small businesses in the country towns and the workers who work for those small businesses. In the country town of Augathella the other day, a small business person rang me and said that he had just shut his small business and put off his worker because he could not continue running his business in that country town. He also said that, in the last four months, seven families had just walked out of their homes and left the town. They could not sell their house. They could not get a job in the area. They have just walked out. The ramifications of this drought go far beyond the farm gate. They are well into the small business sector of the nation, particularly in these drought areas. It is certainly impacting on many families, whether they own a small business or whether they have got a job working for someone in these rural drought areas. I think the full impact of this drought and the drift of population from rural areas will be measured for many years to come. All Australians are waiting to hear what the Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy say today in the package for rural families affected by drought. The package has to extend to assistance to small business. It has got to extend into the area of welfare and it has got to extend into the farmer's financial problems. It has to address those problems. It really took a television personality and Australia wide support for a farmhand appeal before we saw a government willing to move and to visit the drought areas of this nation. I think it is a great tragedy that a government and a Prime Minister could be so out of touch that it took a television personality and the Australian people's contribution to that farmhand appeal to drag in the Prime Minister, albeit in a damage control mode, to see first hand what was happening to families, small businesses and farmers in drought ravaged Australia. Whilst the coalition will not be denying this bi11 a second reading, I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Main Committee, recognising the needs of individuals and families living in rural and regional Australia who face the ravages of severe drought, calls on the Government to make farm household support a grant for up to 12 months and to modify the assets test for other forms of assistance". I hope the government will accept that amendment. If it does not, and if it does not address those issues in the package today, the opposition wi11 be pursuing the government relentlessly on this issue. Ms HENZELL (Capricornia)(10.47 a.m.)-This is the first time. I have spoken in the Main Committee room, so please alert me if I make mistakes. I rise to support the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1994. I will not be supporting the amendment as proposed by the honourable member for Maranoa( Mr Bruce Scott). speaker: Mr Forrest
theText: I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.1324 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 September 1994 registered by the member for Maranoa. I do not believe his suggestion is the way to handle this problem, although I recognise that there are problems associated with the farm household support scheme. It should be noted that this was an attempt to provide for those families who need to be assisted to leave a primary industry. We do not do it in any other industrial sector. The speech by the honourable member for Maranoa, which we all suffered in silence, and the MPI in the House of Representatives yesterday are desperate attempts by those in the National Party to play catch-up. Once again, they have lost the initiative and they have dealt themselves out of the main game. I want to make some comments about the member for Maranoa and, to an extent, some media misrepresentation of comments by the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) in my electorate on 19 July in relation to drought. The Prime Minister has not changed his position. In response to a question on the drought, he said that drought is a continuing factor in this nation. I have spoken to primary producers in central and western Queensland about seasons, and they are the first to admit that this has been a major problem over 60 years on the one land-holding, that often properties are more in drought than out of it, and that across the country at some point in time, and even in the same regions, drought declarations happen very frequently. The Prime Minister's view is that this government will be about bringing in a systemic set of provisions to deal with a very complex issue in our agricultural sector. I think it would be useful to comment on the sort of policy on the run that the National Party is into. We should not look to the Queensland Country Life, which is the bible of most rural producers. It is not surprising to see that the constituency of the National Farmers Federation is sometimes behind its leaders. This was brought home to me during the Prime Minister's tour to central Queensland with representatives from the National Farmers Federation, the Queensland Grains Council and the United Graziers Association. We should not be surprised that peak leaders of organisations are often further advanced in their views because they have the bigger picture. Let me refer, Mr Deputy Speaker, to an article by the Australian's rural writer, Tim Stevens, on 9 September. I happened to be reading this while I was on a flight with the Attorney General( Mr Lavarch) out of Townsville to Charters Towers and to Clermont to visit droughted properties and to talk with local government and rural producers in central western Queensland. The aim of that visit was to further inform other cabinet members on the issues of the drought. It is simply not the case that this government is not interested or sensitive to drought issues. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins, has been into my electorate-and, indeed, into the member for Maranoa's electorate-at least twice this year. Mr Bruce Scott-Twice with no action. when the cabinet brings down the results of its deliberations today. But let us see what a real critique of National Party policy on drought is all about. I quote from Tim Stevens's article, which I had the pleasure to show to the Attorney-General as we flew out of Townsville: It is not often that a conservative politician bearing $90 million in gifts is shown the door by farm leaders. Yet this was the reaction from Coalition backbenchers and the National Farmers Federation to the release of the Opposition's drought policy last week. The policy's key feature, a $90 million scheme to pay for fodder for livestock in "severe" drought areas, was interpreted as a blatant reversion by the Liberal and National parties to the days of unfunded promises, when policies were based overwhelmingly on populist agrarian notions rather than sounder economic rationales.
title: Represent Atives Main Committee

speaker: Ms Henzell
theText: That is not the case, and the proof of the pudding will be in the eatingWednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITIEE 1325 I might add that when the Prime Minister visited and talked with farming families near Dingo he made the point that he was not going to be into cheap gestures and feel-good policies. What this government is about is sound, economically based policies that will provide significant assistance to farming families and to the agricultural sector. Why was this critique made? It was apparently decided on 22 August by a shadow cabinet meeting that drought was obviously going to be a key issue. I quote: It was decided that a comprehensive response was needed of the Government's policies and this was interpreted by John Anderson, the Coalition's primary industries spokesman, as a desire to have a detailed policy and off he went to find one. What the primary industries spokesman came up with was apparently the Fightback package plus this fodder subsidy scheme, which is really revisiting the Fraser government's 1982 scheme. Fodder subsidies have been criticised for the following reasons, and I once again quote Mr Stevens: They provide a disincentive for producers to prepare for drought, which includes the making and storing of hay. They tend to jolt demand, sending fodder prices through the roof. Fodder suppliers and users have rorted the system. I will go on quoting Mr Stevens: Curiously, Anderson mentioned his policies to no one. Despite the stated desire of Opposition Leader Alexander Downer to involve all of the Liberal and National party political processes in decision-making, The Australian has been unable to speak to anyone whose views were sought on drought issues prior to the announcement. The National Farmers Federation was not consulted. The shadow minister did not bother to go on and consult the peak organisation, and in public and in private-although not quoted in the Queensland Country Life-the peak farming bodies of this country were scathing in their criticism. I further quote Mr Stevens: The chairman of the Coalition parliamentary primary industries committee, Neil Andrewwho I see is in the Main Committee room todayfirst knew of the policy on the morning of its release. Embarrassingly, Andrew was later asked to sit next to Anderson during the press conference. Little time was spent debating the policy in the shadow Cabinet of August 29, despite the potential fiscal size of the package, although one proposal from Anderson for concessional loans-to help reconstruct the sector after the drought ends-was sent to a special shadow Cabinet sub-committee. The rest was ticked and sent to a joint meeting of the Liberal National parties the next day, before being released just over one week after shadow Cabinet first asked for a policy. Apparently, this is the way the Coalition's policy making process works these days. There were no offsets sought by shadow Cabinet to counterbalance the increased expenditure. They are all care and no responsibility in the opposition. Mr Stevens continues: The Nationals, it appears on the surface, have reverted to the good old days of pork barrelling and unfunded campaign promises, with the blessing of the Liberals. This, Mr Deputy Speaker, is the sorry state of opposition policy building. This is the policy you have when you try to have a policy. Mr Bruce Scott-Tell us about your policy. not brought on by the media; it was brought on because the Labor government has more rural
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Ms Henzell
theText: We are going to have an excellent policy. The Prime Minister's tour was1326 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 September 1994 representatives in this parliament than the National Party does, and we have a vested interest in making sure that the concerns of the rural and agricultural sector of this country are taken into account. But it will not be done by feel-good throwing money at the problem. It will be done by a systematic approach, to provide effective changes to the rural adjustment scheme and effective responses to the obvious needs and pressures on farm families. One of the factors that I have certainly put forward, apart from looking at an effective way to make sure that the children of farming families are able to access assistance with their schooling, is an issue that has not made the headlines but was put to us at a property south of Charters Towers. It is that we are not talking about only the education of older children, who will need to go away to boarding school to get an education. It is vital that those children do get that education, because it is very clear that many of those children will choose not to return to family properties. They will choose to go into other sectors of the economy. Like all other children in this country, they need to have access to educational opportunities, in order to either choose to go into other sectors or become effective farm managers. Gone are the days when people could go to year 10 and then just go back and learn the job from their parents. The farm sector, like every other industrial sector, has to change and become much more effective in terms of targeting niche markets and so on. It is now a highly skilled operation. But I want to make comment on those children who are being educated at home. The story I want to tell the members attending the Main Committee this morning is one of a young mother who came to the meeting with a lO-week-old baby, the fourth of her children; she had three other children at home. She was lucky enough to have her mother staying with her prior to the birth of this baby, and subsequent to its birth. This young mother is teaching the sevenyear-old at home. Nowadays, that is a full day's occupation. It is not just a matter of setting up some work and going away to do the housework; you are in the schoolroom all day. The second child has been classified as a gifted child, and will, therefore, need particular assistance if its abilities are going to be really provided for. The third child is a toddler. Now, a mother with a lO-week-old baby should be, basically, doing what she can in the house and then feeding that baby and looking after it. At the point in time when this mother came to this meeting with the Attorney-General and myself, her husband had cattle away on agistment, so the only support person she had to look after herself and her four children was her mother. Had her mother not been available, I do not know who would have washed the nappies. I have drawn to the attention of the Prime Minister and other members of the cabinet that we must make sure we are providing for support so that women in this kind of predicament can access assistance. Obviously, it is difficult for families with young children when they drive into town-which may be a twoor three-hour drive-to go to the doctor, just to arrange for occasional child care. At least in Charters Towers there are some doctors who bulk-bill. In many cases in country Queensland, and certainly in Rockhampton, there are almost no doctors who bulk-bill, causing further financial pressure on these families. I can assure members opposite that these family concerns are being addressed, and certainly were addressed by the Prime Minister. As I said yesterday in the caucus meeting, it was very interesting that what was said on the national media was very true during our visit to Timbaroo at Dingo. Farming families were really quite shocked by the fact that, in meeting the Prime Minister, they had to wrestle with their preconceptions about the sort of person he was. Of course, their preconceptions had been based on television media presentations of the Prime Minister, and articles in magazines such as the Queensland Country Life. What they found Wednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1327 was a warm, caring, concerned person who spoke with feeling and was able to yarn on their level. That has been a very important experience for that group of people. I assure you that the Prime Minister is not someone who flourishes a bit of rhetoric just to provide a bit of popular grandstanding. The key point he made at that meeting was: just as we made a commitment not to leave the unemployed behind, we will not leave country people behind. We are aware of the concerns and we will respond to those concerns. We do not need the National Party to bleat here today and to play catch-up to tell this government what is required to provide for people through this drought. One of the issues that I have raised with the Prime Minister is that, as we look at the crisis and the tragedy that is happening to people in this drought, we will certainly have to look at issues about land care and environmental degradation. I will just quote from the minister's second reading speech. In connection with the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993, he stated: Firstly they wiJI ensure that ecologically sustainable development principles are written into the charter of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation and that the membership of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation will include, in future, expertise in environmental and ecological matters. This is going to be an issue that has certainly been brought into stark relief by the drought. What we see, following the extension of rural and agricultural pursuits into marginal country, particularly across northern Queensland, is that where we have drought conditions we have a major long-term impact on the environmental status of the land. An example would have been when Capella, which has had drought for six to eight seasons, got a deluge of rainseven inches in 24 hours. This is pretty typical; it is up the road from Emerald. In a good season, it is one of the most beautiful areas of this country. If we have a droughted area with extensive clearing and then there is a deluge of rain, we have a massive erosion problem. This is a factor that will have to be addressed and will be addressed by this government. We cannot simply allow extension of dry land farming into marginal areas if we expect to keep this country together, ecologically speaking. I will quote from an article by Wallace Brown in the Sunday Mail on 4 September. He was being critical that there was not an effective drought policy. He said: ... the latest survey by the National Farmers' Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation, being joint sponsors of the Landcare program, shows increasing desertification due to clearing of trees and other native vegetation. It is alarming to read that 5000 square km of native vegetation is still being cleared each year in Australia, and that this is an amount comparable to the area cleared in the Amazon Basin, which environmentalists world-wide condemn. We have to face the fact that we have to get back to restoring this country to ecologically sustainable development. Now, belatedly I believe, farming organisations and the National Farmers Federation have come on board on this. This is a very important issue in the government's drought policy. It is not going to be more dams, more water. I have had well meaning and very caring people who want to train water into rural sectors. It is good to see, as unfortunate as it is, that at this time of drought there are very few cattle in the middle of my electorate because the land simply cannot sustain those cattle. We have to recognise that. Yes, indeed, we have to look after breeding stock, but we will not do it by the ill-thought out, ill-considered policies with which the National Party is desperately trying 1328 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 21 September 1994 to hold on to its constituency. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, at the end of the day, the Labor government is increasingly going to take on board that rural constituency. In fact, one of the farmers at the Dingo meeting said to the Prime Minister that he may well be the Prime Minister who saves the bush. As the Prime Minister said in response, that is a very big ask but it will be this government which will put forward very positive policies that will be to the long-term benefit of the rural sector and ecologically sustainable development in this country. to be a decent person but it saddens me that she would stoop to such cheap politics as the contribution we have just heard from her. In fact, it has taken some constraint on my part to listen to her in silence. I think the member for Capricornia should go out and ask the people on the ground what they think of the initiative we are calling for. Go and ask the constituents of the member for Maranoa( Mr Bruce Scott). Go and ask the real people. If the member for Capricornia is so fond of quoting newspaper articles, let me quote to her this one from the Queensland Country Life. This is a newspaper from her own state. She should stay and hear this contribution. It says: A fodder subsidy for drought stricken graziers is one of the most positive and effective forms of assistance. Federal Primary Industries Minister, Bob Collins, is wrong to dismiss it out of hand because it would not work. This was on 8 September. It also states: So why is our national Government so out of step with the opinions of its citizens, choosing instead to fiddle while rural Australia withers? That is by the editor of the Queensland Country Life. If the member for Capricornia is genuine in her sentiments that the Labor Party is going to meet the needs of rural Australia, it ought to be a lot more in touch with what the people there think of its government. People are asking: why can decisions be made, on the run and outside cabinet, that can contribute $150 million to a so-called eyesore in Sydney? This decision was made on the run, outside the executive, by the Prime Minister( Mr Keating). How can sweetheart deals outside cabinet and outside the parliament be made on the run with the Maritime Union of Australia? How can those decisions be made on the run? There are desperate primary producers in the member for Maranoa's electorate. Sadly, the cancerous drought is spreading all the way through New South Wales. Now even in my own electorate of Mallee there will be grain growers who will not harvest wheat or grain of any sort this year because the drought is extending across Australia. They are asking: why do we have to wait three years for decent consideration? This drought has not suddenly arrived. These are the sorts of questions the constituency is asking. It is a pity the member for Capricornia has not stayed. I would suggest that she should get out there and ask the people what they think of the initiatives we announced. Rural Australia is not outer suburbia. Rural Australia is the people out there producing the wealth in the sparsely populated areas of Australia. I think the Labor Party has got a lot of work to do if it thinks it can sustain the confidence of rural Australia. I am not talking about urban suburbs. We are talking about rural Australia where there are 130,000 people in 70-odd thousand square kilometres that are sparsely populated but produce the nation's wealth. theText: I know the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell)Wednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITIEE 1329 can be so hypocritical in its efforts to help its union mates and to preserve the aesthetics for the Prime Minister when they have to wait for decent consideration. I would have expected a better contribution from the member for Capricornia. I will leave it to other members from our side who are present to talk more about the initiatives in our policy other than the fodder subsidy. We talk about reinstalling drought in the national disasters relief arrangements. For the Prime Minister to say that primary producers are expected to prepare for four years of drought indicates how out of touch he is. He has got a long way to go if he is going to save the bush, as the member for Maranoa has said. I will get back to the legislation that is before this Committee, and the motion that the member for Maranoa has put before it. It is true that the majority of the bills that we are considering, particularly those that relate to levies, have general industry support. For someone in a very strong horticultural producing electorate, and especially in regard to wineMr Bruce Scott-Great wine. who was in my electorate for two days last week. We did enjoy the fruit of the vine. The sad contrast was that, with the advantages and asset of the Murray River as an irrigation source, 50 kilometres to the south, we will see grain growers feeding their wheat to their sheep. This is the sad plight of the extension of this drought. I do not think that the Prime Minister-nor the members present, obviously, from the contribution we have just heard-has yet appreciated how insidiously the drought is extending right across Australia. In Swan Hill, my home city, we have a large agricultural machinery producer, producing disc ploughs and marketing right across Australia, to Western Australia, Queensland and indeed, recently, even expanding into exporting. Sadly, a fortnight ago, the firm had to put off five young people, including one apprentice, because of the impact of the drought. That is the extent of the national disaster. It is not just a problem for the Queenslanders. We have heard the stories from members representing those areas-but the drought does extend. There are now five families in Swan Hill upon which the drought has had a direct impact. Their income will be reduced to the extent that they will not be spending in Swan Hill, and so other businesses are impacted by the effects of the drought. It is a national disaster-we have said clearly that this should be recognised. Irrigation from the Murray River, as I have said, is one of the saving resources of an electorate like mine, which is so dependent on the elements. The member for Maranoa has spoken about a number of my industries. He has referred to chickens, and I would much rather focus on horticulture. No-one was more disappointed than me, when I arrived here as a new member of parliament, to listen to the government's August budget in 1993, and hear its proposals to tax the wine industry. The member for Maranoa has already spoken in glowing terms about the expansion that this industry is providing in wealth earning and job creation. The objective of this industry is, by the turn of the century, to triple its export development, which is the billion dollar program that the member for Maranoa has mentioned to the Committee. To see a government picking a winner here, and then choosing to tax it with a WST, instead of a GST-the wholesale sales tax on wine-disappoints me. This is a government that purports to want to initiate regional development and to have an interest in rural Australia.

Subsequent owners of that winery have continued to invest, because they see real opportunities in meeting the targets in the expansion of the wine industry generally. The employment base that that winery now provides to a small community like Red Cliffs, a small rural town which has a population of around about 1,500, is worth millions of dollars to that community. This is an example of real regional development in the most successful terms. I think the government needs to recognise this and encourage enterprises at every opportunity. That is real regional development, that is development that creates jobs. The prospect of a prosperous future in wine grape production gives the community some sense of optimism for the future. I therefore suggest to the government, and those of its members that are present here today, that on all occasions it should work very carefully, through its taxation policies, to ensure that bright, new, expansive industries are encouraged in every way. I would like to comment further on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2). I know that other speakers following will probably do the subject more justice than I can, and the member for Maranoa has already commented on it, but I would like give my observations on how the farm household support scheme is not working. I continue to focus on horticulture. Around the Sunraysia region of my electorate, I have got two principal industries, citrus and dried vine fruit. Both these industries have been asked to bear the pain of being sacrificed on the great altar of free trade. I was annoyed last week, when there were negotiations in respect of the Australian National Line, to hear the union movement arguing its case, saying that its people could not be expected to compete with Third World labour rates. I feel that it is gross hypocrisy that the government has listened to this argument and invested substantial amounts of taxpayers' funds to preserve jobs in that industry. Yet my two industries, worth probably $200 to $250 million dollars per annum just in my electorate, are being asked to compete with cheap labour from Turkey in regard to dried vine fruit and extremely cheap labour and the benefits of critical mass out of Brazil in respect of citrus. I ask the government how it can tolerate this style of hypocrisy. Many of my constituents would say that, true, the ultimate goal must be world free trade and a level playing field and that we are going to have a considerable amount of pain in getting there. They would not mind bearing some of this pain, provided it is shared by all Australians. When an announcement is made outside the cabinet and outside the parliament in regard to the Australian National Line, they just see gross hypocrisy, given that for years now they have been asked to bear considerable pain, go without and even have to suffer the indignity of deciding which of their children will be able to pursue tertiary education. That is a terrible decision for parents to have to make.

theText: A government that went to an electorate and said there would be no newWednesday, 21 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1331 Many of them, particularly in dried vine fruit, elected to take the option in regard to farm household support. Sadly, the situation is that, whilst they were genuine initially in their efforts to discharge their obligation in respect of the ownership of their property, the market is such that there are probably something like 1,000 dried vine fruit properties on the market in the Sunraysia district and properties just do not sell. We have now got a significant number of people who have taken farm household support, gone beyond their nine months, cannot sell their properties and now have to sustain what is being transferred as a commercial loan at commercial interest rates, rates well in excess of 10 per cent. This is an added financial burden on their ability to cope or even to consider how they can restructure and be part of a new industry and to take the opportunities that wine grapes are providing for them. In view of their significant debt as well as this additional debt to the rural finance corporation, I am very concerned about their ability to meet this exciting new initiative in wine grapes, so I put to the government that it should give greater consideration to the wealth producers of my electorate as well as consider the national disaster that this drought represents. I also suggest that when it makes its announcements it should defend itself with respect to the time it has taken to announce drought policy to meet the needs of hurting people, particularly Queenslanders and people from New South Wales, because those people can see hypocrisy in terms of the way the government assists its friends. I also remind members of the government of a number of problems with regard to salinity control and the sustaining of water reserves in the Murray-Darling Basin. In fact, this summer there is no doubt that the Darling River will have a blue-green algal burst that will see the last one in 1992 fade into insignificance. My horticulturalists are being asked to contribute to salinity mitigation from a variety of sources, but to do so while their financial circumstances are so fragile is an additional burden they cannot sustain. Some are being asked to contribute to modifications to their supply system where open channels are being converted to pipelines, which often requires a capital cost contribution. Others are being asked to make contributions through local government levies through their municipal rates. I put it to the government that the ability of the horticulturalists to meet these contributions has been substantially eroded by years of neglect and that it is time that the Minister for Resources, the honourable member for Rankin( Mr Beddall), and the government considered the dried vine fruit growers and citrus growers in my electorate. Every retailer in a community where primary commodities are not doing well is also not doing well so we are speaking on behalf of small business across rural Australia as well as the primary producers themselves.
